 I know you are probably tired of hearing things from me, but I just have to point out that the refraction at the surface of water does not change because there is no light coming from beneath, it is only the fact that it is black in the background that causes the reflection to be the only noticed light.
 
 As an experiment you can get a black container and a clear (or white) container and fill them both with water and let them settle.
 
 See which one seems like a mirror.
 
 Well they are both reflecting the same light at the same rate but it is washed out by the white (or bright on what ever you set them on) that's transmitting through the water.
 
 Now there is a compound effect, since the sky AND water are both blue the total reflected blue light is a sum of both.
 
 The blue light flying around the atmosphere reflecting off the water, the blue light flying around the water coming out at you which is coming from both surviving light from the sun and initially blue light from the sky.
 
 The final effect is that it is very rare for water to not look blue at all, but we do get lots of shades.
 
 I live by the Chesapeake bay and we have A LOT of plant life in here and that causes a consistent green color, yet the water still looks very blue (you can tell it's green by swimming in it or looking at a shadowy area.
 
 It's abundantly clear that this is being caused by the skies reflection.
 
 Anyway I would be surprised if the oceans looked anything but blue from outer space, it's reflective, it's blue itself, and the whole earth has a blue tint especially off of any white or reflective surface on it due to the atmosphere.
 
 Finally green is green, even from a plane forests look like a green plane with no discernible color difference, you may also note that satellite photos with color are always of areas lit by the sun, on the surface we are used to partial shade in which colors look darker.

While I'm not certain which phenomenon works on the outer appearance of water, I can add something as a diver.
 
 Water is not entirely clear and does absorb visible light. It especially starts at the red end of the spectrum. As a consequence, the deeper one goes under the water, the more light is absorbed, leaving only the blue hues.
 
 One can go to ten meters, grab a beautiful purple object, and find out it's actually dull brick red on the surface. To see the true colors, flashlights are needed. Interestingly, your eyes and mind adapt to the all blue surroundings so the areas illuminated with regular white light will then look reddish when you first look at them. But the colours get quite vivid at times.
 
 Whether absorbtion or refraction is what causes blue in satellite imagery, I'm not sure, though.

Um, I'm pretty sure that you got that wrong here.
 
 The light we get on the surface is white - it's direct white light coming through the atmosphere.
 
 Near the surface, it illuminates everything in white - if you look at an object under an inch or water, the colour won't change from what you see holding it in the air.
 
 However, as you go down, the initially white light (IE, all wavelengths) starts to get absorbed by the water (which absorbs much more light than the air). All light gets absorbed, but the red end of the spectrum is hit first/harder. What remains is the blues, and so the deeper one goes, the less light there is to see by and the more blue it all seems.
 
 I would especially point to the "underwater_3" picture above - the effect is clearly seen once you realize part of the picture is actually illuminated by a flashlight. The tray or boat that the diver is holding is of one colour, but the parts closer to the photographer are illuminated and in the natural colour, while the parts further back already show the bluish tinting since the flash didn't reach that far.
 
 As a matter of fact, light CANNOT penetrate deeper than a certain depth, I think it's 200 metres. It's dark below there and photosynthesis becomes impossible, so there's much less life below that threshold.
 
 I don't know why the sky is blue or why the ocean seen from above is blue. I'll have to look it up.
